subtitles.text: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
Hmm.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now, let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean, look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in, and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water, making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper, and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.

If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg, too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile, that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetablefree.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce.
Add more pasta water if needed to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional grated pecorino romano and black pepper before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Cooked bacon, some reserved for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon and cook it in a pan until it is crispy. Reserve some of the cooked bacon for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Bacon is used instead of guanciale, which is traditional for carbonara, because this is not a traditional carbonara recipe.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Turn off the burner and let the bacon cool to avoid overcooking the egg-based sauce later.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Cheese and Eggs-2
materials: Pecorino Romano cheese, which is a hard, salty Italian cheese made from sheep's milk, typically used in carbonara.
Egg yolks, which are the yellow part of an egg, rich in fats and proteins, used to create a creamy sauce.
Black pepper, a spice made from the dried fruit of the Piper nigrum plant, used for seasoning.
outcomes: A mixture of grated cheese, egg yolks, and pepper, which forms the base of the sauce for the pasta.
tools: Cheese grater, a kitchen utensil used to grate cheese into fine pieces.
Hand gesture muscles, humorously referred to as a tool for grating cheese.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate the Pecorino Romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks. Mix them together until you achieve a creamy consistency. Add black pepper to the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The cheese and egg yolk mixture is the base for the sauce, which will coat the pasta and provide flavor and creaminess.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you want to shred your Pecorino more easily, you can use a drill with a screw, although this is presented humorously and not recommended.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the egg-based sauce, as it can ruin the texture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-3
materials: Spaghetti: Long, thin pasta used as the main ingredient.
Salt: White crystalline substance used to season the water.
outcomes: Spaghetti cooked until al dente: The pasta is firm to the bite, indicating it is properly cooked.
tools: Pot: A large container used to boil water and cook the spaghetti.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water in a pot, add salt to the water, and then add 156 pieces of spaghetti. Stir the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together. Cook the spaghetti until it is al dente.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reason for adding salt to the water is to season the pasta as it cooks. Stirring the spaghetti initially helps prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Keep stirring the spaghetti initially to prevent it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Breaking spaghetti in half is considered a crime in Italy and can ruin the texture of the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Crispy bacon, with some reserved for garnish
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Chop the bacon and cook it in a frying pan until it becomes crispy. Reserve some of the crispy bacon for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon is cooked until crispy to add texture and flavor to the dish, and some is reserved for garnish to enhance presentation.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is cooked evenly by stirring occasionally.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon, as it can become too hard and lose its flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Mix Egg Mixture-5
materials: Pecorino Romano cheese (visual: finely grated cheese)
outcomes: The cheese in the egg mixture melts smoothly (visual: creamy, smooth sauce)
tools: Bowl (visual: a mixing bowl for combining ingredients)
Whisk or fork (visual: utensil for mixing)
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add a bit of pasta water into the egg yolk and pecorino cheese mixture to help melt the cheese and create a smooth sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water helps to melt the cheese and create a creamy texture in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Make sure the pasta water is hot to aid in melting the cheese efficiently.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to add too much pasta water at once, as it can make the sauce too runny.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
outcomes: A creamy sauce coating the spaghetti
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the burner and let the bacon cool until there's no sizzle left. Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients to help melt the cheese. Transfer the noodles directly from the water into the bacon pan and mix. Add the sauce, allowing the egg to cook from the heat of the noodles. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce, adding more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency. Finish with pepper and more cheese.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The bacon needs to cool to prevent overcooking the egg-based sauce. Pasta water is added to help melt the cheese and create a creamy sauce. The heat from the noodles is sufficient to cook the egg in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce. The pasta water helps achieve the desired creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon is cooled sufficiently to avoid overcooking the egg-based sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Reserve Pasta Water-7
outcomes: Reserved pasta water for use in the sauce
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Before draining the spaghetti, set aside some pasta water.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The reserved pasta water is used to help create a creamy sauce by adding it to the sauce ingredients.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
outcomes: A creamy sauce coating the spaghetti
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the burner and let the bacon cool. Add a bit of pasta water to the sauce ingredients. Transfer noodles directly from the water into the bacon pan. Add the sauce to the noodles, allowing the egg to cook from the noodle heat. Optionally, put the pan on low heat to thicken the sauce. Add more pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency. Finish with pepper and cheese.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The egg will cook just enough from the heat of the noodles, and adding pasta water helps achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you strain the spaghetti, set aside some pasta water to use in the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the bacon is cool enough before adding the egg-based sauce to prevent overcooking.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-9
materials: Pecorino or Parmesan cheese: A hard, salty cheese used for grating over the pasta.
Pepper: Freshly ground black pepper to add spice and flavor.
Reserved bacon: Cooked bacon pieces set aside earlier in the process.
outcomes: The pasta is garnished with additional cheese, pepper, and bacon, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
tools: Grater: Used to grate the cheese over the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the dish by adding some freshly ground pepper, more grated pecorino or parmesan cheese, and the reserved bacon on top of the pasta before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding more cheese, pepper, and bacon at the end enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more appealing and delicious.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use freshly grated cheese and freshly ground pepper for the best flavor.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to add too much cheese or pepper, as it can overpower the dish.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Mix the grated cheese into the egg mixture.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Bacon is crispy and some is reserved for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Slice the bacon into thick pieces, about three-quarters of an inch. Turn a pan on to medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and slowly render out the fat, cooking until the bacon is crispy. Reserve some crispy bacon for garnish by draining it on a paper towel.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy, which is desirable for both the pasta and as a garnish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Thick cut bacon is preferred for better texture and flavor.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Bring a pot of water to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the water. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti. Cook the spaghetti for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Use tongs to remove the spaghetti from the pot.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because there are many salty elements in carbonara. The spaghetti is cooked slightly al dente because it will be finished in the bacon pan.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to handle the spaghetti easily. Leave the pasta water in the pot after removing the spaghetti, as it can be used later to adjust the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti. It should be slightly al dente as it will continue to cook when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Cheese and Eggs-3
materials: Pecorino Romano cheese (sheep's milk cheese, aged)
outcomes: A mixture of finely grated Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese combined with eggs and pepper, forming a smooth egg mixture.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate about three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese using a fine setting on a cheese grater or box grater. In a bowl, combine three whole eggs and two egg yolks, and whisk them together. Gradually whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until smooth. Add fresh ground black pepper to taste and whisk it in.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The mixture of both Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheeses is used to achieve a balanced flavor. The combination of whole eggs and egg yolks provides richness without being overly heavy. Adding black pepper is a matter of personal preference, enhancing the flavor of the mixture.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you don't have a cheese grater, use the fine setting on a box grater to achieve the desired cheese texture. Adjust the amount of black pepper according to your taste preference.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Bacon-1
outcomes: Bacon is crispy and some is reserved for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Slice the bacon into thick pieces, about three-quarters of an inch. Turn a pan on to medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Break the bacon into the pan and slowly render out the fat, cooking until crispy. Reserve some crispy bacon for garnish by draining it on a paper towel.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Rendering the fat slowly allows the bacon to become crispy, which is desirable for both the pasta and as a garnish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Thick cut bacon is best for this recipe.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the bacon.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Spaghetti-2
outcomes: Spaghetti is cooked to al dente, ready to be mixed with the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Fill a pot with about four quarts of water and bring it to a boil. Add about a tablespoon of kosher salt to the boiling water. Once the water is boiling, add the spaghetti. Cook the spaghetti for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente. Use tongs to remove the spaghetti from the pot, leaving the water in the pot.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because carbonara has many salty elements. The spaghetti is cooked until slightly al dente because it will finish cooking in the sauce. The pasta water is left in the pot to be used later if needed to adjust the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use tongs to remove the spaghetti from the pot to retain the pasta water for later use in adjusting the sauce consistency.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be careful not to overcook the spaghetti as it will continue to cook when mixed with the sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Ingredients-6
outcomes: The spaghetti is coated in a velvety, fluffy, creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
The sauce is creamy and smooth, with no cream added.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Use tongs to transfer the cooked spaghetti into the pan with the bacon fat. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti. Gently mix to coat the spaghetti with the sauce, ensuring the eggs do not scramble. If the sauce is too thick, add a little pasta water to loosen it.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: The heat from the spaghetti will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. The pasta water can be used to adjust the sauce's consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If the sauce doesn't thicken as desired, you can place the pan over simmering pasta water to gently heat it further. Use pasta water to adjust the sauce's thickness.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Ensure the heat is off to prevent scrambling the eggs. Be gentle with the pasta to avoid breaking it.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-7
outcomes: The pasta is garnished with additional cheese, pepper, and crispy bacon, enhancing its flavor and presentation.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Plate the pasta using tongs. Finish by sprinkling additional Parmigiano Reggiano cheese over the pasta. Add some of the reserved crispy bacon on top for added crunch. Optionally, add more freshly ground black pepper to taste.
subgoal_summaries.explanations: Adding more cheese and bacon on top enhances the flavor and provides a satisfying texture contrast with the creamy pasta. The crispy bacon adds a crunch that complements the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the bacon is crispy before using it as a garnish to add a pleasant texture contrast to the creamy pasta.
subgoal_summaries.warnings: Be gentle when plating the pasta to avoid breaking it.

metadata.title: Pasta Carbonara the American Way (With Bacon)

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Bacon
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop and cook bacon until crispy, reserving some for garnish.
original_steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil (optional).
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan. Turn off the heat.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Spaghetti
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil water, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.
original_steps: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot, add salt, and cook spaghetti until al dente.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Cheese and Eggs
subgoal_definitions.description: Grate cheese and prepare the egg mixture with cheese and pepper.
original_steps: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano Reggiano cheese.
Mix the grated cheese into the egg mixture.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Add fresh ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture.

subgoal_definitions.title: Reserve Pasta Water
subgoal_definitions.description: Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
original_steps: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Mix Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Add pasta water to the egg and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
original_steps: If needed, add a little pasta water to loosen the sauce and achieve a creamy consistency.
Add a small amount of pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix cooked spaghetti with bacon and egg mixture to create a creamy sauce.
original_steps: Transfer the cooked spaghetti to the pan with bacon using tongs, leaving the pasta water in the pot.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the hot spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
